awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Towards Fatigue Behavior Prediction of Structural Materials through Computationally-Informed Textural and Microstructural Characteristics
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) project will integrate mechanics of deformations at multiple length scales to discover how the microstructure of a metal influences the distribution of local stress (force over nominal area) that drive failure under cyclic loading. Failure of structural materials by fatigue -- the accumulation of damage under cyclic loading -- remains one of the major challenges in mechanics and materials science. Crucially, the mechanisms through which applied mechanical loading distributes between regions called grains within the microstructure are not fully understood. The novelty of the computational approach to be used in this project is to explicitly target the grain boundaries, which will inherently connect multiple scales relevant to fatigue crack nucleation and growth. Knowledge of the correlations between the microstructure and fatigue crack driving forces will enable tailored material design. Recent advances in additive manufacturing technology have enabled control of microstructure during material deposition. This research will yield a theoretical and computational framework for designing structural components to capitalize on this flexible manufacturing technology. Thus, the research will advance national health, prosperity, welfare, and defense, while progressing science. The research outcomes of the project will be integrated with specific K-12 and underrepresented minority outreach activities as well as support foundational research in vectors education. Making physics concepts easier will empower students to succeed and bring new perspectives to their future STEM careers. Curriculum enhancements will directly impact courses at the 11th grade up to graduate level; broader impact is achieved through teaching new pedagogies to educators.

The goal of this research is to advance the understanding of microstructural and textural influences on fatigue behavior of polycrystalline materials by understanding how stress applied at the bulk scale is redistributed at the grain scale. The primary research objective is to discover how grain interactions, called the neighborhood effect, influence the distribution of local stresses that drive fatigue crack nucleation and growth. The novel approach involves decomposing the balance of forces and displacement jumps along grain boundaries into contributions from the granular uniform field (mesoscale) and fluctuation field (microscale). A multi-resolution Discontinuous Galerkin method is developed to measure the neighborhood effect that is ideally-suited for capturing discontinuities along grain boundaries, allowing contributions from mesoscale and microscale to be distinguished but not having to be separated. Hypotheses are pursued to reveal the relative zone of influence of mesoscale versus microscale stress components, thereby elevating the empirical nature of fatigue threshold design to account for microstructural and textural features that increase resistance to small crack growth. Insight as to how these local effects propagate through the microstructure and affect material fatigue would provide a better understanding of why some flaws nucleate cracks while others do not. This project launches the PI towards becoming a national leader in the prediction of engineering scale fatigue properties for polycrystalline structural materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This CAREER award has contributed to the development of interfacial formulations that couple micro-, meso-, and macro-scales with the aim of understanding the mechanisms governing local stress distribution in polycrystalline materials. The novel approach of this project was to explicitly target traction equilibrium and displacement compatibility along the grain boundary that inherently connect all three scales.  The result of this research was an extended Hill-Mandel homogenization principle for multiscale analysis that includes disequilibrium and incompatibility effects using grain boundary jump terms. Also, the first-ever finite strain viscoplastic symmetric Discontinuous Galerkin method has been developed which is suitable for representing damage and jumps along microscale interfaces in the context of large plastic deformations. This formulation has been implemented and verified in an application named BEAVER of the open-source MOOSE finite element framework and is available for public use. Another key outcome of these developments was a unified computational platform for testing various formulations of periodic boundary conditions, a crucial component of all microstructural mechanics models. This exploration identified formulations well suited to iterative solvers that enable scaling up the computational domain size and effectively using high performance computing for modeling fatigue and creep behavior of material microstructures.

This CAREER project also produced a range of educational and outreach impacts across two major thrusts: enabling a holistic approach to vector instruction in high school and college curricula, and engaging underrepresented student groups in hands-on experiences with the mechanics of microstructures. Many studies have observed students struggling with vector-related concepts in mechanics, and these struggles negatively impact student success and pursuit of engineering careers.  Thus, enhancements were made to a first-year course, a second-year course, and a graduate course in the college of engineering to make vectors education a visual, interactive experience related to real-world phenomena. These developments employing a unified approach of relating a vector’s abstract nature of magnitude and direction to its geometric nature as length and unit vector have impacted hundreds of students in the college. Also, to address high school students’ exposure to vectors in physics prior to attending college, a vectors education workshop was developed for teachers through the Oak Ridge Associated Universities (ORAU) K-12 Educator Programs. This workshop was co-developed and taught by the PI and a local high school teacher for five summers through ORAU, ultimately reaching 40 middle and high school math and science teachers across the country. During the six-hour workshop, these teachers were exposed to pedagogy such as the use of interaction diagrams as a bridge to drawing forces on free body diagrams as well as hand-on and virtual tools for engaging students about the use of vectors. Aligned with the second thrust, a research project on mechanics of materials and modeling microstructures was hosted amongst several other projects in the college of engineering within the HITES12 program. This project explored computational materials science and the effect of geometry in multiphase materials, with the application of using additive manufacturing to design a material with intermediate effective properties. For four summers, groups of three to four underrepresented minority students worked weeklong on the project alongside graduate students in the PI's laboratory to culminate in a presentation to their peers and mentors about the designed microstructure.

Also, this project contributed to the technical and professional development of a range of budding scholars. Six undergraduate researchers were mentored and supported through this grant and its supplements, including one female student and one underrepresented minority student. These students engaged in scripting and using finite element software which they would not otherwise have encountered in traditional civil engineering curriculum. The project also supported four graduate students and one research associate who have now transitioned to careers in industry and national laboratories. These researchers and the PI have disseminated their work through two MS theses, three PhD dissertations, several journal publications and working papers, and more than ten conference talks. Overall, this CAREER award not only enhanced our knowledge of mechanical modeling of interfaces within polycrystalline materials, but also will have a lasting impact through the teachers, researchers and engineers who have been touched by its outreach and scholarship.


Last Modified: 10/22/2024
Modified by: Timothy J Truster
